    <div class="docs markdown"><div class="pilwrap" id="nodemailer">
  <h1>
    <a href="#nodemailer" name="nodemailer" class="pilcrow"></a>
Nodemailer
  </h1>
</div>
<p><a href="https://nodemailer.com/about/"><img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/nodemailer/nodemailer/master/assets/nm_logo_200x136.png" alt="Nodemailer"></a></p>
<p>Send emails from Node.js ‚Äì easy as cake! üç∞‚úâÔ∏è</p>
<p><a href="https://nodemailer.com/about/"><img src="https://nodei.co/npm/nodemailer.png?downloads=true&amp;downloadRank=true&amp;stars=true" alt="NPM"></a></p>
<p>See <a href="https://nodemailer.com/">nodemailer.com</a> for documentation and terms.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>[!TIP]
Check out <strong><a href="https://emailengine.app/?utm_source=github-nodemailer&amp;utm_campaign=nodemailer&amp;utm_medium=readme-link">EmailEngine</a></strong> ‚Äì a self-hosted email gateway that allows making <strong>REST requests against IMAP and SMTP servers</strong>. EmailEngine also sends webhooks whenever something changes on the registered accounts.<br>
<br>
Using the email accounts registered with EmailEngine, you can receive and <a href="https://emailengine.app/sending-emails?utm_source=github-nodemailer&amp;utm_campaign=nodemailer&amp;utm_medium=readme-link">send emails</a>. EmailEngine supports OAuth2, delayed sends, opens and clicks tracking, bounce detection, etc. All on top of regular email accounts without an external MTA service.</p>
</blockquote>
<div class="pilwrap" id="having-an-issue">
  <h2>
    <a href="#having-an-issue" name="having-an-issue" class="pilcrow"></a>
Having an issue?
  </h2>
</div>
<div class="pilwrap" id="first-review-the-docs">
  <h4>
    <a href="#first-review-the-docs" name="first-review-the-docs" class="pilcrow"></a>
First review the docs
  </h4>
</div>
<p>Documentation for Nodemailer can be found at <a href="https://nodemailer.com/about/">nodemailer.com</a>.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="nodemailer-throws-a-syntaxerror-for...">
  <h4>
    <a href="#nodemailer-throws-a-syntaxerror-for..." name="nodemailer-throws-a-syntaxerror-for..." class="pilcrow"></a>
Nodemailer throws a SyntaxError for &quot;...&quot;
  </h4>
</div>
<p>You are using an older Node.js version than v6.0. Upgrade Node.js to get support for the spread operator. Nodemailer supports all Node.js versions starting from Node.js@v6.0.0.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="im-having-issues-with-gmail">
  <h4>
    <a href="#im-having-issues-with-gmail" name="im-having-issues-with-gmail" class="pilcrow"></a>
I'm having issues with Gmail
  </h4>
</div>
<p>Gmail either works well, or it does not work at all. It is probably easier to switch to an alternative service instead of fixing issues with Gmail. If Gmail does not work for you, then don't use it. Read more about it <a href="https://nodemailer.com/usage/using-gmail/">here</a>.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="i-get-etimedout-errors">
  <h4>
    <a href="#i-get-etimedout-errors" name="i-get-etimedout-errors" class="pilcrow"></a>
I get ETIMEDOUT errors
  </h4>
</div>
<p>Check your firewall settings. Timeout usually occurs when you try to open a connection to a firewalled port either on the server or on your machine. Some ISPs also block email ports to prevent spamming.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="nodemailer-works-on-one-machine-but-not-in-another">
  <h4>
    <a href="#nodemailer-works-on-one-machine-but-not-in-another" name="nodemailer-works-on-one-machine-but-not-in-another" class="pilcrow"></a>
Nodemailer works on one machine but not in another
  </h4>
</div>
<p>It's either a firewall issue, or your SMTP server blocks authentication attempts from some servers.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="i-get-tls-errors">
  <h4>
    <a href="#i-get-tls-errors" name="i-get-tls-errors" class="pilcrow"></a>
I get TLS errors
  </h4>
</div>
<ul>
<li>If you are running the code on your machine, check your antivirus settings. Antiviruses often mess around with email ports usage. Node.js might not recognize the MITM cert your antivirus is using.</li>
<li>Latest Node versions allow only TLS versions 1.2 and higher. Some servers might still use TLS 1.1 or lower. Check Node.js docs on how to get correct TLS support for your app. You can change this with <a href="https://nodejs.org/dist/latest-v16.x/docs/api/tls.html#tls_tls_createsecurecontext_options">tls.minVersion</a> option</li>
<li>You might have the wrong value for the <code>secure</code> option. This should be set to <code>true</code> only for port 465. For every other port, it should be <code>false</code>. Setting it to <code>false</code> does not mean that Nodemailer would not use TLS. Nodemailer would still try to upgrade the connection to use TLS if the server supports it.</li>
<li>Older Node versions do not fully support the certificate chain of the newest Let's Encrypt certificates. Either set <a href="https://nodejs.org/dist/latest-v16.x/docs/api/tls.html#tlsconnectoptions-callback">tls.rejectUnauthorized</a> to <code>false</code> to skip chain verification or upgrade your Node version</li>
</ul>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-keyword">let</span> configOptions = {
    <span class="hljs-attr">host</span>: <span class="hljs-string">'smtp.example.com'</span>,
    <span class="hljs-attr">port</span>: <span class="hljs-number">587</span>,
    <span class="hljs-attr">tls</span>: {
        <span class="hljs-attr">rejectUnauthorized</span>: <span class="hljs-literal">true</span>,
        <span class="hljs-attr">minVersion</span>: <span class="hljs-string">'TLSv1.2'</span>
    }
};
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="i-have-issues-with-dns-hosts-file">
  <h4>
    <a href="#i-have-issues-with-dns-hosts-file" name="i-have-issues-with-dns-hosts-file" class="pilcrow"></a>
I have issues with DNS / hosts file
  </h4>
</div>
<p>Node.js uses <a href="https://nodejs.org/en/docs/meta/topics/dependencies/#c-ares">c-ares</a> to resolve domain names, not the DNS library provided by the system, so if you have some custom DNS routing set up, it might be ignored. Nodemailer runs <a href="https://nodejs.org/dist/latest-v16.x/docs/api/dns.html#dnsresolve4hostname-options-callback">dns.resolve4()</a> and <a href="https://nodejs.org/dist/latest-v16.x/docs/api/dns.html#dnsresolve6hostname-options-callback">dns.resolve6()</a> to resolve hostname into an IP address. If both calls fail, then Nodemailer will fall back to <a href="https://nodejs.org/dist/latest-v16.x/docs/api/dns.html#dnslookuphostname-options-callback">dns.lookup()</a>. If this does not work for you, you can hard code the IP address into the configuration like shown below. In that case, Nodemailer would not perform any DNS lookups.</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-keyword">let</span> configOptions = {
    <span class="hljs-attr">host</span>: <span class="hljs-string">'1.2.3.4'</span>,
    <span class="hljs-attr">port</span>: <span class="hljs-number">465</span>,
    <span class="hljs-attr">secure</span>: <span class="hljs-literal">true</span>,
    <span class="hljs-attr">tls</span>: {
        <span class="hljs-comment">// must provide server name, otherwise TLS certificate check will fail</span>
        <span class="hljs-attr">servername</span>: <span class="hljs-string">'example.com'</span>
    }
};
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="i-have-an-issue-with-typescript-types">
  <h4>
    <a href="#i-have-an-issue-with-typescript-types" name="i-have-an-issue-with-typescript-types" class="pilcrow"></a>
I have an issue with TypeScript types
  </h4>
</div>
<p>Nodemailer has official support for Node.js only. For anything related to TypeScript, you need to directly contact the authors of the <a href="https://www.npmjs.com/package/@types/nodemailer">type definitions</a>.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="i-have-a-different-problem">
  <h4>
    <a href="#i-have-a-different-problem" name="i-have-a-different-problem" class="pilcrow"></a>
I have a different problem
  </h4>
</div>
<p>If you are having issues with Nodemailer, then the best way to find help would be <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/search?q=nodemailer">Stack Overflow</a> or revisit the <a href="https://nodemailer.com/about/">docs</a>.</p>
